items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.     
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  
Although levels have declined slightly during the last few weeks, we expect levels to remain high and low lying land and roads therefore remain at risk of flooding.  
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.  
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 28 April or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at our Snailwell Borehole remain high but are slowly falling. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. No significant rainfall is currently forecast, however there is a risk that the groundwater levels will continue to remain high over the next week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 28th April, or as the situation changes.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds. First forecast high water is 07:45 on 27/04/2021 with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 4 North-Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 20:00 on 27/04/2021 with a level of 6.71 mAOD and a Force 5 North-Westerly wind.

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible at these times and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.    
Strong onshore winds will cause tide levels to rise further.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates where appropriate and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches and coastal footpaths.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tides on Tuesday 27th, Wednesday 28th and Thursday 29th April due to high spring tides. Water levels will be raised between the period of 05:00 tomorrow, 27th April and 19:45 on Thursday, 29th April. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect  coastal and tidal areas between Hartland Point and Lynmouth, including the Taw Torridge Estuary. 
 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the highest forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is at 06:30 on Wednesday at 5.09m AOD.

Waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides. Flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible tomorrow, Tuesday 27 April between 10:00 and 14:00. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. It is forecast that the high tides at midnight on Tuesday and lunchtime on Wednesday will also reach the Flood Alert threshold. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon 27/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. First forecast high water is 07:15 on 27/04/21 with a level of 7.40 mAOD and a Force 2 South Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 19:30 on 27/04/21 with a level of 7.52 mAOD and a Force 2 West North Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Properties are unlikely to flood at this point but tides are rising and we will be updating this flood alert for the remainder of the week. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Tuesday 27/04/2021.

The high tide is expected to be higher than usual as a result of high tides. Consequently flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible from 11:45am today 27/04/21.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry between 11:45am and 12:30pm, with a peak of 6.26m, Eastford Road between 12:00pm  and 12:45pm, with a peak of 6.41m, and Arpley Bridge between 12:15pm and 13:00pm, with a peak of 6.46m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. Based on current forecast, the next high tide is not expected to reach flood alert threshold, however, the midday tide tomorrow 28/04/21 is expected to reach the flood alert threshold. We will issue further updates to this message as necessary.

Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 19:00 and 20:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 27/04/21. Flooding of the promenade and seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.

We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront. The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.56 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.04 m. The forecast tide level is 4.52 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is east south east. The forecast wind strength is Force 4.
